item.title: The math on AI agents doesn’t add up
item.description:
PLUS: What hallucinations reveal about the future of automation.

View in browser  |  Update preferences 

■ In this week’s Backchannel: A research paper suggests AI agents are mathematically doomed to fail. The industry doesn’t agree.

 

Agentic AI is both impossible and inevitable at the same time

The big AI companies promised us that 2025 would be “the year of the AI agents.” It turned out to be the year of talking about AI agents, and kicking the can for that transformational moment to 2026 or maybe later. But what if the answer to the question “When will our lives be fully automated by generative AI robots that perform our tasks for us and basically run the world?” is, like that New Yorker cartoon, “How about never?”

That was basically the message of a paper published without much fanfare some months ago, smack in the middle of the overhyped year of “agentic AI.” Entitled “Hallucination Stations: On Some Basic Limitations of Transformer-Based Language Models,” it purports to mathematically show that “LLMs are incapable of carrying out computational and agentic tasks beyond a certain complexity.” Though the science is beyond me, the authors—a former SAP CTO who studied AI under one of the field’s founding intellects, John McCarthy; and his teenage prodigy son—punctured the vision of agentic paradise with the certainty of mathematics. Even reasoning models that go beyond the pure word-prediction process of LLMs, they say, won’t fix the problem.

“There is no way they can be reliable,” Vishal Sikka, the dad, tells me. After a career that, in addition to SAP, included a stint as Infosys CEO and an Oracle board member, he currently heads an AI services startup called Vianai. “So we should forget about AI agents running nuclear power plants?” I ask. “Exactly,” he says. Maybe you can get it to file some papers or something to save time, but you might have to resign yourself to some mistakes.

The AI industry begs to differ. For one thing, a big success in agent AI has been coding, which took off last year. Just this week at Davos, Google’s Nobel-winning head of AI, Demis Hassabis, reported breakthroughs in minimizing hallucinations, and hyperscalers and startups alike are pushing the agent narrative. Now they have some backup. A startup called Harmonic is reporting a breakthrough in AI coding that also hinges on mathematics—and tops benchmarks on reliability.

Harmonic, which was cofounded by Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev and Tudor Achim, a Stanford-trained mathematician, claims this recent improvement to its product called Aristotle (no hubris there!) is an indication that there are ways to guarantee the trustworthiness of AI systems. “Are we doomed to be in a world where AI just generates slop and humans can't really check it? That would be a crazy world,” says Achim. Harmonic’s solution is to use formal methods of mathematical reasoning to verify an LLM’s output. Specifically, it encodes outputs in the Lean programming language, which is known for its ability to verify the coding. To be sure, Harmonic’s focus to date has been narrow—its key mission is the pursuit of “mathematical superintelligence,” and coding is a somewhat organic extension. Things like history essays—which can’t be mathematically verified—are beyond its boundaries. For now.

Nonetheless, Achim doesn’t seem to think that reliable agentic behavior is as much an issue as some critics believe. “I would say that most models at this point have the level of pure intelligence required to reason through booking a travel itinerary,” he says.

Both sides are right—or maybe even on the same side. On one hand, everyone agrees that hallucinations will continue to be a vexing reality. In a paper published last September, OpenAI scientists wrote, “Despite significant progress, hallucinations continue to plague the field, and are still present in the latest models.” They proved that unhappy claim by asking three models, including ChatGPT, to provide the title of the lead author’s dissertation. All three made up fake titles and all misreported the year of publication. In a blog about the paper, OpenAI glumly stated that in AI models, “accuracy will never reach 100 percent.”

Right now, those inaccuracies are serious enough to discourage the wide adoption of agents in the corporate world. “The value has not been delivered,” says Himanshu Tyagi, cofounder of an open source AI company called Sentient. He points out that dealing with hallucinations can disrupt an entire work flow, negating much of the value of an agent.

Yet the big AI powers and many startups believe these inaccuracies can be dealt with. The key to coexisting with hallucinations, they say, is creating guardrails that filter out the imaginative bullshit that LLMs love to produce. Even Sikka thinks that this is a probable outcome. “Our paper is saying that a pure LLM has this inherent limitation—but at the same time it is true that you can build components around LLMs that overcome those limitations,” he says.

Achim, the mathematical verification guy, agrees that hallucinations will always be around—but considers this a feature, not a bug. “I think hallucinations are intrinsic to LLMs and also necessary for going beyond human intelligence,” he says. “The way that systems learn is by hallucinating something. It’s often wrong, but sometimes it's something that no human has ever thought before.”

The bottom line is that like generative AI itself, agentic AI is both impossible and inevitable at the same time. There may not be a specific annum that will be looked back upon as “the year of the agent.” But hallucinations or not, every year from now on is going to be “the year of more agents,” as the delta between guardrails and hallucinations narrows. The industry has too much at stake not to make this happen. The tasks that agents perform will always require some degree of verification—and of course people will get sloppy and we’ll suffer small and large disasters—but eventually agents will match or surpass the reliability of human beings, while being faster and cheaper.

At that point, some bigger questions arise. One person I contacted to discuss the hallucination paper was computer pioneer Alan Kay, who is friendly with Sikka. His view is that “their argument was posed well enough to get comments from real computational theorists.” (A statement reminiscent of his 1984 take on the Macintosh as “the first personal computer good enough to be criticized.”) But ultimately, he says, the mathematical question is beside the point. Instead, he suggests people consider the issue in light of Marshall McLuhan’s famous “Medium is the message” dictum. “Don’t ask whether something is good or bad, right or wrong,” he paraphrases. “Find out what is going on.”

Here’s what’s going on: We may well be on the cusp of a massive automation of human cognitive activity. It’s an open question whether this will improve the quality of our work and our lives. I suspect that the ultimate assessment of that will not be mathematically verifiable.

Time Travel

I was heartened that Tudor Achim spoke well of hallucinations, because two years ago I wrote “In Defense of AI Hallucinations,” a piece that embraced the possibility that AI would never rid itself of its troublesome inaccuracies. Like Achim, I celebrated the creative spirit of AI confabulation. But I also conjectured that as long as chatbots got stuff wrong, we wouldn’t let them take over the world. I’m not so sure about the last part anymore.

Santosh Vempala, a computer science professor at Georgia Tech, has also studied hallucinations. “A language model is just a probabilistic model of the world,” he says, not a truthful mirror of reality. Vempala explains that an LLM’s answer strives for a general calibration with the real world—as represented in its training data—which is “a weak version of accuracy.” His research, published with OpenAI’s Adam Kalai, found that hallucinations are unavoidable for facts that can’t be verified using the information in a model’s training data.

That’s the science/math of AI hallucinations, but they’re also notable for the experience they can elicit in humans. At times, these generative fabrications can seem more plausible than actual facts, which are often astonishingly bizarre and unsatisfying. How often do you hear something described as so strange that no screenwriter would dare script it in a movie? These days, all the time! Hallucinations can seduce us by appearing to ground us to a world less jarring than the actual one we live in. What’s more, I find it telling to note just which details the bots tend to concoct. In their desperate attempt to fill in the blanks of a satisfying narrative, they gravitate toward the most statistically likely version of reality as represented in their internet-scale training data, which can be a truth in itself. I liken it to a fiction writer penning a novel inspired by real events. A good author will veer from what actually happened to an imagined scenario that reveals a deeper truth, striving to create something more real than reality.

Ask Me One Question

Alexandra asks, “How do tech journalists stay curious without getting cynical?"

Thanks for the question, Alexandra. It’s helpful that you gave a clue as to what you meant by sharing that you are recovering from tech burnout and are worried about returning to that world “without falling back into the toxic parts.” So what you are saying is that some of the unattractive aspects of techland—selfish oligarchs, enshittified products, and the pursuit of progress without sufficient regard for what benefits society—can nullify what’s truly exciting about the field.

I can’t speak for all tech journalists, but what keeps me from being cynical is a perpetual fascination with the technology itself and the people who lend their creativity and acumen to building breakthrough products and making cutting-edge discoveries. For instance, I found that writing the backstory of the invention of AI transformers was inspiring, fun, and instructive.

And if some of those people turn to the dark side? Hey, that’s interesting too. Instead of fomenting cynicism, bad behavior on the part of powerful tech people calls for the scrutiny that journalists can and should exercise. Identifying the flaws in our world doesn’t make us cynical—beaming sunshine in dark corners is actually a hopeful act, urging people to do better. Even if fanboys rip us on social media for our work.

Quote of the Week

“[AI] may go too fast for society … Should you do it all at once? No. You will have civil unrest. So phase it in.”

—JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, speaking at Davos in favor of hitting the brakes on AI.

What did you think about today's newsletter? Let me know by emailing me at backchannel@wired.com

In Other News

  • We Are Witnessing the Self-Immolation of a Superpower With Donald Trump’s actions in Greenland, Minneapolis, and Venezuela, a foreign enemy could not invent a better chain of events to wreck the standing of the United States.
  • Chinese EV Batteries Are Eating the World China’s lithium batteries aren’t always “made in China.” Companies like BYD and CATL are building factories on nearly every continent.
  • Your First Humanoid Robot Coworker Will Probably Be Chinese Explosive acceleration, limited dexterity, eyes in the back of its head. What could possibly go wrong?

Made in China

Sign up

Resident AI expert Will Knight takes you to the furthest edges of this fast-changing field

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 23, 2026
I was banned from Claude for scaffolding a Claude.md file?
• Article: https://hugodaniel.com/posts/claude-code-banned-me/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46723384
• Score: 616
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • A developer using Anthropic's Claude AI for personal coding projects faced an account ban after automating prompts resembling system instructions, triggering moderation heuristics. The ban occurred without warning or explanation, highlighting the opaque nature of AI moderation systems.
  • • The developer's project involved running two Claude instances to iterate on scaffolding tools, but the process was flagged as a violation, possibly due to prompt injection concerns. The incident underscores challenges in using AI tools for advanced automation.
  • • Following the ban, the developer received a refund but no communication or support from Anthropic. The experience raises concerns about AI safety protocols prioritizing extreme caution over user engagement and accuracy.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • **Service Reliability and Customer Support**: Many commenters shared frustrations with Anthropic's Claude service becoming unreliable, with issues such as flakiness, failed prompts, and unresponsiveness. A recurring theme was the lack of adequate customer support, which often consists of automated responses or an AI bot, with human escalation being rare or ineffective.
  • • **Account Bans and Lack of Transparency**: Several users reported being banned from Claude without clear explanations or recourse, sometimes after seemingly innocuous actions like using a VPN or submitting certain prompts. The lack of transparency in the banning process and appeals system was widely criticized.
  • • **Prompt Injection and Automation Concerns**: The discussion included speculation about bans being triggered by activities perceived as prompt injection or automation misuse, such as using Claude to modify its own behavior or scaffolding projects.
  • • **Alternatives to Claude**: Commenters debated other LLMs like ChatGPT, Gemini, and open-source models such as GLM, Mistral, and locally hosted solutions. Some expressed preference for open-source models to avoid corporate control and censorship.
  • • **Ethical and Systemic Issues**: The conversation touched on broader concerns about corporate control over AI tools, lack of accountability, and the implications of centralized AI systems on users' freedom and livelihoods.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreement**: There was widespread consensus that Anthropic's customer support and transparency need significant improvement. Many commenters agreed that the lack of human support and unclear banning policies create a poor user experience.
  • • **Disagreement**: Opinions varied on the viability of alternatives to Claude. Some praised open-source models for independence, while others argued they lag behind proprietary models in quality and reliability. There was also debate over whether Anthropic's bans were justified or overly harsh.
  • • **Mixed Sentiments on AI Moderation**: While some supported strict moderation for safety, others criticized the over-reliance on automated systems and the lack of human oversight.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment was predominantly negative, with many users expressing frustration, disappointment, and distrust toward Anthropic's handling of Claude's reliability and support issues. Some commenters were optimistic about alternatives, while others were skeptical of their capabilities.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • • **Local Models as a Solution**: Several commenters advocated for running local LLMs to avoid corporate restrictions and bans, emphasizing the importance of decentralization in AI.
  • • **Anthropic's Strategic Risk**: One commenter highlighted the potential damage to Anthropic's reputation if it doesn't trust its own AI for customer support, questioning why corporate clients should rely on Claude.
  • • **Broader Implications**: Commenters discussed the risks of centralized AI tools potentially barring users from industries or workflows, likening it to monopolistic control.
  • 5. **Recurring Issues**:
  • • **Token Usage and Costs**: Users reported dissatisfaction with unclear token limits and pricing, particularly for high-cost plans like Claude Max.
  • • **Automation and Prompt Injection**: Many commenters speculated that Anthropic's automated systems flagged benign actions as malicious, leading to bans.
  • • **Calls for Regulation**: Some commenters advocated for legal frameworks to prevent arbitrary bans and ensure accountability in AI services.
  • 6. **Notable Comments**:
  • • A commenter highlighted the chilling effect of Anthropic's banning practices on developers, discouraging investment in Claude-specific tools.
  • • Another user suggested prompt injection techniques could be exploited maliciously to ban organizations from AI tools.
  • • Discussions on open-source models like Mistral and GLM provided valuable insights into alternatives to proprietary LLMs.
  • In summary, the discussion underscored dissatisfaction with Anthropic's service reliability, customer support, and banning policies, while exploring alternatives and raising broader concerns about corporate control in AI.

Article Summary:

  • • Proton sent an email promoting its AI feature, Lumo, to a user who had explicitly opted out of Lumo-related communications, raising concerns about privacy and consent. The email was labeled as part of the "Proton for Business" newsletter, which the user disputes as misleading.
  • • The incident highlights broader issues within the AI industry, where companies often disregard user preferences and consent, pushing AI into products and services without explicit approval. This trend is criticized for undermining trust and violating ethical standards.
  • • The user calls out Proton's handling of the situation, emphasizing the growing problem of non-consent in tech, especially within the AI sector, which frequently sidesteps privacy laws and user autonomy.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics of Discussion**:
  • • **Proton's Marketing Practices**: Many commenters criticized Proton's intrusive marketing emails, particularly around their AI product "Lumo." Users expressed frustration over receiving promotional emails despite opting out, with some suggesting this behavior undermines trust in the company.
  • • **AI and Consent**: The broader issue of AI being forcefully integrated into products and services without user consent was heavily discussed. Commenters noted that AI marketing often disregards user preferences, reflecting a trend of non-consensual implementation across the tech industry.
  • • **Comparison to Competitors**: Several commenters highlighted their dissatisfaction with Proton's overall suite of products, including email and VPN services, and shared positive experiences with alternatives like Fastmail and Tutanota.
  • • **Ethics and Accountability in Tech**: Commenters debated the ethical implications of marketing practices and the lack of consumer protection in the tech industry, pointing out that GDPR enforcement is limited outside of Europe.
  • • **Broader Tech Industry Trends**: Some commenters linked Proton's behavior to a larger trend of "enshittification," where companies prioritize profit over user experience and trust as they scale.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreement**: Many commenters agreed that Proton's marketing practices, particularly around AI, are problematic and erode trust. There was consensus that non-consensual marketing emails are unethical and frustrating.
  • • **Disagreement**: While most criticized Proton, a few defended the company, arguing that the issue might stem from technical errors or misclassification rather than malice. Others felt the complaints were exaggerated and suggested unsubscribing was a simple solution.
  • • **AI-Specific Criticism**: Some commenters believed the issue is specific to AI hype and marketing, while others argued this behavior is typical of marketing teams in general, regardless of the product being promoted.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion was largely negative, with commenters expressing dissatisfaction with Proton's marketing practices and broader trends in the tech industry. Frustration and distrust were common sentiments, especially regarding AI-related marketing and lack of respect for user preferences.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters shared personal experiences with Proton and other companies, highlighting issues like slow product development, poor customer support, and misleading marketing practices.
  • • A commenter provided a detailed perspective on how internal conflicts between support and marketing teams might lead to such incidents, offering insight into corporate dynamics.
  • • Comparisons to competitors like Fastmail and Tutanota revealed that users prioritize simplicity, reliability, and trust in their choice of email providers.
  • 5. **Key Takeaways**:
  • • Proton's marketing practices, particularly around AI, have led to significant user frustration and loss of trust.
  • • The tech industry's disregard for user consent in marketing and product integration is a widespread issue, with AI being a focal point.
  • • Many users are considering or have already switched to competitors due to dissatisfaction with Proton's products and practices.
  • • Ethical concerns and lack of accountability in tech marketing were recurring themes in the discussion.

The state of modern AI text to speech systems for screen reader users
• Article: https://stuff.interfree.ca/2026/01/05/ai-tts-for-screenreaders.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46730346
• Score: 49
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Despite advancements in AI-driven text-to-speech (TTS) technology, blind screen reader users remain underserved due to their unique needs for speed, clarity, and efficiency over natural-sounding voices. Popular systems like Eloquence, last updated in 2003, are outdated and difficult to maintain.
  • • Modern AI TTS models, such as Supertonic and Kitten TTS, face critical issues like dependency bloat, inaccuracy, slow response times, and lack of customization, making them unsuitable for screen readers.
  • • The community faces significant challenges in modernizing TTS systems for blind users, with potential solutions requiring millions in funding and expertise in linguistics, signal processing, and programming. Advocates hope for increased awareness and collaboration to address these gaps.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion revolves around the limitations and challenges of modern AI-based text-to-speech (TTS) systems, particularly in the context of screen readers used by blind individuals.
  • 2. A key theme is the mismatch between the goals of AI TTS systems and the specific needs of screen reader users. Commenters noted that while AI voices aim to sound natural and human-like, blind users prioritize speed, accuracy, and predictability, which modern systems often fail to deliver.
  • 3. Several commenters expressed frustration with AI TTS models, citing issues such as skipping words, mispronouncing numbers, generating garbled speech artifacts, and slower response times compared to legacy systems like Eloquence and ESpeak. These older systems, though outdated, are still favored by many blind users due to their efficiency and reliability.
  • 4. Some commenters provided technical insights into the limitations of current models, suggesting that implementation choices and architectural issues may be contributing to the problems. For instance, one commenter argued that modern systems could be optimized by tweaking chunk sizes for streaming, though this was debated by others.
  • 5. There is a general sentiment of concern and pessimism regarding the future of screen reader technology. Commenters highlighted the lack of overlap between modern TTS research and the needs of blind users, as well as the dwindling support for legacy systems. One commenter estimated that modernizing the preferred TTS stack would require significant funding and expertise, which seems unlikely to materialize.
  • 6. Broader accessibility issues were raised, such as the lack of support for screen readers in Linux Wayland environments and the proprietary protocols introduced by GNOME, which further complicate adoption. This has led some users to consider switching to Windows despite reservations.
  • 7. A few commenters proposed potential solutions, such as reverse-engineering older systems like Eloquence, though others pointed out the technical complexity and legal barriers involved.
  • 8. The sentiment across the discussion was mixed but leaned toward skepticism and disappointment. While some commenters praised the advancements in AI TTS models for general use, many agreed that these systems are not yet suitable for screen reader users and fail to address their unique requirements.
  • 9. One insightful comment suggested that AI's potential lies beyond improving screen readers and could instead serve as a conversational assistant for blind users, offering a more interactive and task-oriented experience.
  • 10. Overall, the discussion highlighted the gap between technological innovation in AI TTS and practical accessibility needs, with a consensus that significant improvements are required before these systems can effectively replace legacy solutions for screen readers.

4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Incidentally, among AI subreddits, grok stands atop the leaderboard for NSFW mention frequency, if that’s any indication of where the action lies.</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Well, we can’t really say that consumers are buying OnlyFans for the articles. But, as Jonathan Coopersmith most famously laid out, there is a long tradition of vice driving the leading edge of tech, especially video, including editing, distribution, and compression. iOS apps in the app store.</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">After basically zero growth for the past three years, new app releases surged 60% yoy in December (and 24% on a trailing twelve month basis).</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">It’s starting to feel like 2008, when Apple first released the iPhone SDK (now called the iOS SDK). While it initially debuted with approximately 500 third-party apps, app downloads surpassed 1M in the first weekend (and reached ~1B by early 2009). More apps drew more eyeballs which drew more apps, all of which eventually unlocked hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue for app developers (and a multi-trillion dollar ecosystem that no one had ever heard of a decade prior).</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">AI is similarly opening up an entirely new surface area for value creation, and mobile is emerging as an early winner on the frontier.</p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Microsoft released an “AI Diffusion” map, demonstrating the share of the working age population using a generative AI application during the second half of 2025. While adoption is increasingly widespread, there is a clear regional divergence such that “adoption in the Global North grew nearly twice as fast as in the Global South.”</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Somewhat surprisingly, the UAE sits atop the leaderboard (followed closely by Singapore), with ~64% of the working age population adopting AI (at least once, during the measured period).</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">The US, for its part, increased adoption by ~2 percentage points since the first half of the year, but actually slipped a spot in the rankings from 23rd to 24th (following a big jump by South Korea).</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Microsoft points out that AI adoption is hard to measure, so this is really just one way of looking at the picture, but it’s striking nonetheless.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Adoption is increasing pretty much everywhere, with roughly the entirety of the OECD demonstrating at least 20% adoption. If the adoption gap continues to widen, though, one can only imagine that the second- and third-order effects of being an “AI have v. AI have-not” will be amplified.</span><span class="footnote-anchor-email" data-component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOMStatic" style="font-size: 20px;">³</span></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Five of the biggest listed alcohol producers are sitting on a combined ~$22B of inventory, the highest level in more than a decade (and an increasingly large share of total sales).</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Remy Cointreau really breaks the scale with ~€1.8B in aging sprits that’s nearly double its annual revenues, and more than 80% of the company’s total market cap</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">No one knows precisely why alcohol sales have disappointed quite so much (and there probably isn’t one reason). Likewise, some part of the inventory build is the result of over-producing in response to a pandemic bump in sales (that turned out to be temporary).</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>That all being said, whether it’s GLP-1s, shifting consumer preferences (especially among younger folks), Chinese tariffs, and/or something else entirely, drinking as a global pastime has surely fallen off the wagon (at least for now).</span><span class="footnote-anchor-email" data-component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOMStatic" style="font-size:
